isis.stitle: Recall 99507 - Hydraulic Park Brake Hoses on 4700 Models

recall.subject: Hydraulic Park Brake Hoses on 4700 Models

defect.para: The park brake hand control valve hydraulic hoses may leak at any time without warning under normal driving conditions. Improper hose routing may induce hose rupturing due to chafing, scraping, or rubbing. The park brake will automatically apply if pressure is lost due to a ruptured park brake hose and could cause a vehicular accident, resulting in possibly one or more of the following: property damage, personal injury, or death.

Navistar will notify owners of this campaign on their vehicles. A listing of owner names and addresses has been furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners to have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

para.emph: Before performing the service repair, please read and understand the following instructions completely.

warning.para: To prevent eye injury, always wear safe eye protection.
Block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving.

svcproc.para: 1. Inspecting all park brake hoses for chafing.
2. Replacing any damaged park brake hoses found during the inspection.
3. Re-routing the hoses at the park brake hand control valve ( Figure 1).
4. Installing a hose routing kit ( Figure 1).

step1.para: INSPECT ALL PARK BRAKE HOSES FOR CHAFING. Follow all park brake hoses from the hand control valve down to the transmission looking for spots on the hoses that may be chaffed and may lead to a rupture.
Chafing is most likely to be caused by one of the following conditions.

item.para: Fender well rubbing hoses as the hood is raised or lowered.
The corner of the cab sled runner mounted stand-off bracket cutting into hoses (see Figure 2).
Fender well edge cutting hoses as hood vibrates in the closed position.
Hoses rubbing on shock absorber stud and upper shock mount.

step1.para: Replace the park brake hoses that were damaged from chafing.

The most common hose to be damaged is the supply port hose (the most inboard hose) because it is furthest forward at the valve and is most likely to be scraped by the fender well. Part numbers for the supply port hose are provided in the Parts section of this letter.
Re-route the hoses at the park brake hand control valve from the vertical routing to a horizontal routing (see Figure 1).

step2.para: Remove the hand control valve.

step3.para: Loosen but do not remove the three hoses at the hand control valve.
Remove the cotter pin at the end of the control cable.
Remove the two screws holding the valve to the bracket.
Completely remove the three hoses at the valve.

step2.para: Re-clock the fittings on the hand control valve (see Figure 1).

step3.para: Gently secure the valve in a brass jawed vise to allow access to the three fittings.

Note: The valve ports are labeled on the valve body: exhaust, delivery, and supply. Remove the 90 degree fitting in the supply port (most inboard fitting) and replace it with the straight fitting from kit # 8900068R91. Apply some pipe sealant to the threads of the fitting before installing it (see Figure 1).
Remove the 90 degree exhaust port fitting from the valve (most outboard fitting). This fitting is the one that has the push on hose with a hose clamp.

Rotate the 90 degree delivery port fitting approximately 270 degrees clockwise (tightening) so that it directs the hose in the same direction as the straight fitting that you installed in the supply port (step 3.B.2. above). If the fitting cannot be tightened enough to allow the hose to be directed in the same direction as the supply port then remove the fitting and re-install it with some pipe sealant on the threads to obtain the desired fitting direction.
Re-install the exhaust port fitting, with pipe sealant, to direct the hose in the same horizontal direction as the supply and delivery ports (see Figure 1).

step2.para: Re-install the valve on the mounting bracket.
Do not install the hoses at the valve until instructed below.

Remove the p-clamp and stand-off bracket that holds the hoses to the cab sled runner. Set these parts aside. The p-clamp, bolt, and washer will be reused on vehicles with I-6 engines but these parts will not be used for V-8 engines.
Untangle the three hoses that go to the valve to improve the hose routing.

Be sure the blue hose that goes to the brake booster is routed behind the three hoses that go to the valve. This will prevent the blue hose from contacting the moving hood/fender well parts (see Figure 1).
Re-connect and tighten the supply hose to the valve.
Re-connect and tighten the delivery hose to the valve (the middle port).
Route the exhaust hose from the power steering reservoir so that it lays on top of the other hoses going to the valve (see Figure 3). Reconnect and tighten the hose to the valve with the hose clamp.

Use one of the three new p-clamps from the hose routing kit and put the p-clamp around the hoses at the cab sled runner (see Figure 1). Mount p-clamp to sled runner with the self tapping screw from the kit (see Figure 4 for screw hole location).
Install a tie-strap around the hoses between the valve and the p-clamp (see Figure 1).

Tighten the engine ground bolt at the frame rail then install the extension clip in a vertical position, without the p-clamps, on the engine ground bolt by using the nut and lock washer from the kit (see Figure 5 and Figure 6).

Install the p-clamps around the hoses and bolt the p-clamps to the extension clip (see Figure 5 and Figure 6). Route the hoses along the frame rail through the lower p-clamp. Route the supply port hose, the delivery hose, and the blue hose through the upper p-clamp on the extension clip (see Figure 5 and Figure 6). Figure 6 shows the proper orientation of the p-clamps to the extension clip with the bolt coming up from the bottom, then through the lower p-clamp, then through the extension clip, then through the upper p-clamp. The lock washer and nut should be on top.
Install a tie-strap around all the hoses directly above the shock absorber stud (see Figure 3).

For V-8 engines: Slide under the vehicle and check all hoses along the side of the transmission for chafing points. Install tie straps as necessary to avoid chafing of hoses. Note: V-8 model repairs are complete after step L is performed. The following additional steps are specifically for I-6 engines.

Using the 1/4 inch bolt, washer, and p-clamp that was removed from the stand-off bracket, install the p-clamp to the bracket just above the left engine mount (see Figure 7). This bracket has a hole in it with a weld nut for the 1/4 inch bolt. One of the hoses might not fit in this p-clamp. If one of the hoses does not fit, then tie strap it to the hoses that are routed through the p-clamp.
Install tie straps around the hoses, one about 8 inches forward of the p-clamp installed in step M and one about 10 inches rearward of the p-clamp (see Figure 7).
Check the hoses at the side of the engine and transmission for chafing points. Install tie straps as necessary to avoid chafing of hoses.
Fill power steering fluid reservoir.
Start engine and apply and release park brake a few times. Be sure the power steering reservoir does not run dry.
Check all hose and fitting connections for leaks.
Check park brake for proper operation.
Top off power steering reservoir.

laborinfo.para: Every vehicle in this recall must have labor operation one or two performed and some may have labor operation three performed.

entry.para: Inspect hoses and install hose routing kit for V-8 engines
Inspect hoses and install hose routing kit for I-6 engines
Replace one chafed hydraulic park brake hose, 0.3 hour/ hose.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified IMMEDIATELY from your dealer location.
Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired with 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.
However, consistent with the customer notification, dealers are expected to complete the repairs on the mutually agreed upon service date.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair their vehicle as soon as possible.

claims.para: Refer to Dealer Warranty Manual for procedures to conduct Recall Campaigns.

It is important that the Recall Coding be completed properly to assist in processing the warranty claim. Complete instructions will be found in the Warranty Manual, Section 7-1. Special attention should be given to Items 39 through 44.

responex.para: We ask for your full cooperation and follow-up to this important subject matter. If you have any questions, or need further assistance, please contact the Regional Service Manager at your regional office.
